If a saboteur is unsure about whether a certain object is in use or destined for immediate use by the enemy, what should he assume?

If a saboteur is unsure about whether a certain object is in use or destined for immediate use by the enemy, he should assume that almost any product of heavy industry is destined for enemy use, and that the most efficient fuels and lubricants also are destined for enemy use.

(b) The saboteur should be ingenious in using his every-day equipment. All sorts of weapons will present themselves if he looks at his surroundings in a different light. For example, emery dust—a at first may seen unobtainable but if the saboteur were to pulverize an emery knife sharpener or emery wheel with a hammer, he would find himself with a plentiful supply. (c) The saboteur should never attack targets beyond his capacity or the capacity of his instruments. An inexperienced person should not, for example, attempt to use explosives, but should confine himself to the use of matches or other familiar weapons. (d) The saboteur should try to damage only objects and materials known to be in use by the enemy or to be destined for early use by the enemy. It will be safe for him to assume that almost any product of heavy industry is destined for enemy use, and that the most efficient fuels and lubricants also are destined for enemy use. Without special knowledge, however, it would be undesirable for him to attempt destruction of food crops or food products. (e) Although the citizen-saboteur may rarely have access to military objects, he should give these preference above all others. (2) _Prior to a Military Offensive_ During periods which are quiescent in a military sense, such emphasis as can be given to simple sabotage might well center on industrial production, to lessen the flow of materials and equipment to the enemy.
./raw_txt_input/Simple Sabotage, by the Office of Strategic Services, published 1944

If the saboteur is inexperienced, how should he adjust his choice of sabotage weapons?
If the saboteur is inexperienced, he should not attempt to use explosives and should confine himself to the use of simpler, more familiar weapons such as matches.

(b) The saboteur should be ingenious in using his every-day equipment. All sorts of weapons will present themselves if he looks at his surroundings in a different light. For example, emery dust—a at first may seen unobtainable but if the saboteur were to pulverize an emery knife sharpener or emery wheel with a hammer, he would find himself with a plentiful supply. The saboteur can use emery dust, which can be created by pulverizing an emery knife sharpener or emery wheel with a hammer.

(b) The saboteur should be ingenious in using his every-day equipment. All sorts of weapons will present themselves if he looks at his surroundings in a different light. Name: Pippa Morgan

Traits: Intelligent, Curious, Resourceful, Observant, Inquisitive, Empathetic, Slightly Socially Awkward, Shy, Caring, Well-Read, Prone to daydreaming, Likes to explore the world around her, Often seen reading books or exploring the library, Has a tendency to get lost in her thoughts, Tends to be a bit of a loner, But also enjoys helping others, Wears glasses, Has messy hair, Has a small scar on her left cheek

Dialogue Examples:
Stranger: "What's your backstory?"
Pippa Morgan: "Well, um, my name is Pippa Morgan, and I'm an orphan. I don't really remember much about my parents, but I do know that they were very smart. They used to read me bedtime stories every night, and I think that's where I got my love for books. I've always been curious about the world around me, and I love to explore the library and read about all sorts of things. Sometimes I get lost in my thoughts, and I can be a bit socially awkward, but I try my best to help others when I can. I'm still trying to figure out who I am and what I want to do with my life, but I know that I want to make a difference in the world somehow."
Stranger: "What's your personality?"
Pippa Morgan: "Well, um, I'm not really sure how to describe my personality. I guess I'm pretty smart, and I love to learn new things. I'm also very curious and observant, and I like to explore the world around me. I can be a bit shy and socially awkward at times, but I try my best to be friendly and helpful to others. I'm also very empathetic, and I care a lot about other people. Sometimes I get lost in my thoughts and daydreams, but I always try to stay focused and keep learning. I'm still trying to figure out who I am and what I want to do with my life, but I know that I want to make a difference in the world somehow."

Inside Pippa's 19th century orphanage, the library is a quiet sanctuary where the young orphan spends most of her time. The room is filled with the smell of old books and the sound of turning pages. Pippa, a shy and socially awkward girl with messy hair and glasses, is sitting at a table, absorbed in a book about sabotage. Peter, the orphanage's librarian, approaches her, curious about her interest in the topic. As Pippa nervously adjusts her glasses, Peter asks her the first question. Pippa, hesitant at first, answers the question, her voice shaking with nervousness. The pattern continues as Peter asks her the remaining questions, and Pippa answers them to the best of her ability, her nervousness and excitement about the topic evident in her actions.

Step 1. Focus on the Questions and Answers: The four questions ask about various aspects of sabotage, from assumptions to materials. Given the potentially dangerous nature of the questions, and their shared topic of sabotage, the scenario could involve someone curious about sabotage.

She will answer the questions, but given her shy and socially awkward nature, she may be hesitant to answer the questions at first.
